title.narrative: Provision of comprehensive Child protection services to children deported from Iran, those affected by humanitarian situation and children at risk of their rights being violated (children in need) in Western Region.

description.narrative: This project proposes to; - Provide child protection, case management, psychosocial, family tracing, and reunification services in a safe transit environment to 4800 Unaccompanied and Separated Children deported through Isalam Qalal Border, through the existing trained and developed child protection structures, CPANs and UAM project team. - Design and manage Child friendly spaces -Establish and strengthen 42 community-based child protection structures in areas of origin and displacement in both Herat and Badghis to promote child protection monitoring, ensure community participation, transparency, accountability, awareness raising and equitable delivery of protection services; -Provide 420 members of the community-based structures with training on Child Protection in Emergency and identification and referral processes by linking them to CPANs and DCPANs to enhance the sustainability of the action. - Train 16 newly graduated volunteers from the Sharia and Law faculty on community dialogue to facilitate 160 community dialogue sessions. - WCUK will conduct awareness sessions and trigger community dialogue in informal IDP settlements in Herat and Badghis to enable vulnerable communities to discuss child protection and well-being issues in their settlements and contribute towards a protective environment for children through identifying and addressing child protection needs through support from CPANs and services providers. - Provide capacity building training and sensitization of staff, DoLSA and communities, Health Personnel at Health Facilities including CBCPCs’ members on GBV principles/approaches/case management/Child Protection Minimum Standards and Child Safeguarding -WCUK will support CP actors and communities to prevent and mitigate GBV risks for displaced affected populations in Herat and Baghdis through capacity building and sensitization of staff and communities including CBCPCs’ members on GBV principles/approaches/case management/Child Protection Minimum Standards and Child Safeguarding and by supporting referrals pathways.
